Package com.thomsonreuters.upa.codec

Provides classes and interfaces for encoding and decoding various messages and other data content.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AckMsg
    UPA acknowledgment message is sent from a provider to a consumer to indicate receipt of a specific message.
    Array
    A UPA Array is a uniform primitive type that can contain 0 to N simple primitive entries,u where zero entries indicates an empty Array.
    ArrayEntry
    UPA entry for Array that can house only simple primitive types such as Int, Real, or Date.
    Buffer
    UPA Buffer represents some type of user-provided content along with the content's length.
    CloseMsg
    UPA close message is used by a Consumer to indicate no further interest in a stream.
    DataDictionary
    A class that houses all known fields loaded from an RDM field dictionary and their corresponding enum types loaded from an enum type dictionary.
    Date
    Represents bandwidth optimized date value containing month, day, and year information.
    DateTime
    Represents the date and time (month, day, year, hour, minute, second, millisecond, microsecond, and nanosecond) in a bandwidth-optimized fashion.
    DecodeIterator
    An iterator for decoding the RWF content.
    DictionaryEntry
    A data dictionary entry, containing field information and an enumeration table reference if present.
    Double
    UPA 8-byte double value
    ElementEntry
    An entry for UPA ElementList that can house any DataTypes, including primitive types, set-defined types, or container types.
    ElementList
    The ElementList is a self-describing container type that can contain zero to N^23 element entries, where zero indicates an empty element list.
    ElementSetDef
    Represents a single element set definition, and may define content for multiple entries in an ElementList.
    ElementSetDefDb
    Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can groups ElementListSet definitions together.
    ElementSetDefEntry
    A UPA entry that defines how to encode or decode an ElementEntry.
    EncodeIterator
    An iterator for encoding the RWF content.
    Enum
    Represents an enumeration type, defined as an unsigned two-byte value.
    EnumType
    A single defined enumerated value.
    EnumTypeTable
    A table of enumerated types.
    FieldEntry
    An entry for a UPA FieldList that can house any DataTypes including primitive types, set-defined types, or container types.
    FieldList
    A container of field identifier - value paired entries, each known as a FieldEntry.
    FieldSetDef
    Represents a single field set definition and can define the contents of multiple entries in a FieldList.
    FieldSetDefDb
    Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can group FieldListSet definitions together.
    FieldSetDefEntry
    A UPA entry that defines how to encode or decode a FieldEntry.
    FilterEntry
    An entry for a UPA FilterList that can house only other container types.
    FilterList
    The FilterList is a non-uniform container type of filterId - value pair entries.
    Float
    UPA 4-byte floating point value
    GenericMsg
    A bi-directional UPA message that does not have any implicit interaction semantics associated with it, thus the name generic.
    GlobalElementSetDefDb
    Global Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can groups ElementListSet definitions together.
    GlobalFieldSetDefDb
    Global Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can groups FieldListSet definitions together.
    Int
    A signed integer that currently represents a value of up to 63 bits along with a one bit sign (positive or negative).
    LocalElementSetDefDb
    Local Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can groups ElementListSet definitions together.
    LocalFieldSetDefDb
    Local Message Field List Set Definitions Database that can groups FieldListSet definitions together.
    Map
    The Map is a uniform container type of associated key - value pair entries, each known as a MapEntry.
    MapEntry
    An entry for a UPA Map that can house only other Container Types.
    Msg
    Communicates data between system components: to exchange information, indicate status, permission users and access, and for a variety of other purposes.
    MsgKey
    UPA Message Key houses a variety of attributes used to help identify the contents flowing within a particular stream.
    PostMsg
    UPA Post Message allows a Consumer application to push content to upstream components.
    PostUserInfo
    The PostUserInfo contains information that identifies the user posting this information.
    Priority
    Consumers use Priority to indicate the stream's level of importance, conveyed by the priority information.When a consumer is aggregating streams on behalf of multiple users, the priority typically corresponds to the number of users interested in the particular stream.
    Qos
    UPA Quality of Service class contains information rate and/or timeliness information.
    Real
    This type allows the user to represent fractional or decimal values, with minimal conversion overhead, by using a number and a format hint.
    RefreshMsg
    UPA RefreshMsg contains payload information along with state, QoS, permissioning, and group information.
    RequestMsg
    UPA RequestMsg is used by an OMM consumer to express interest in a particular information stream.
    RmtesBuffer
    This buffer is used by the RMTES Decoding interface to store and display the decoded strings.
    RmtesCacheBuffer
    This buffer is used by the RMTES Decoding interface to store data that needs to be decoded, and used for partial data storage.
    RmtesDecoder
    Used to decode RMTES data from a Buffer using RmtesBuffer and RmtesCacheBuffer.
    Series
    The Series is a uniform container type that contains 0 to N^33 entries where where zero indicates an empty series.
    SeriesEntry
    An entry in a Series container that can house other container types only.
    State
    State conveys data and stream health information.
    StatusMsg
    UPA Status Message is used to indicate changes to the stream or data properties.
    Time
    The UPA Time type allows for bandwidth optimized representation of a time value containing hour, minute, second, millisecond, microsecond, and nanosecond information.
    UInt
    UPA Unsigned Integer type.
    UpdateMsg
    UPA Update Message is used by Interactive and Non-Interactive Providers to convey changes to data associated with an item stream.
    Vector
    The Vector is a uniform container type of index-value pair entries.
    VectorEntry
    An entry for the UPA Vector that can house other Container Types only.
    XMLDecoder
    The UPA XML Decoder.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AckMsgFlags
    Specifies a combination of bit values indicating special behaviors and the presence of optional content for an AckMsg.
    CloseMsgFlags
    Specifies a combination of bit values indicating special behaviors and the presence of optional content for a CloseMsg.
    Codec
    Collection of interfaces to query supported RWF versions for encoder/decoder as well as RWF protocol type being used by the connection.
    CodecFactory
    Factory for encoder/decoder package objects.
    CodecReturnCodes
    Return codes associated with UPA Codec package.
    CodecUtils
    Codec utility methods.
    CopyMsgFlags
    Specifies a combination of bit values indicating how Msg is copied.
    DataStates
    Provides information on the health of the data flowing within a stream.
    DataTypes
    Defines enumerations for UPA primitive and container types.
    ElementListFlags
    Combination of bit values that indicate whether optional, element-list content is present.
    FieldListFlags
    Combination of bit values that indicates the presence of optional field list content.
    FilterEntryActions
    Action to perform on a FilterList for the given filter item.
    FilterEntryFlags
    A combination of bit values that indicate the presence of optional FilterEntry content.
    FilterListFlags
    A combination of bit values to indicate presence of optional FilterList content.
    GenericMsgFlags
    Specifies a combination of bit values indicating special behaviors and the presence of optional content.
    MapEntryActions
    Action to perform on a Map for the given map entry.
    MapEntryFlags
    Combination of bit values to indicate the presence of any optional MapEntry content.
    MapFlags
    Combination of bit values to indicate the presence of optional Map content.
    MfFieldTypes
    Enumerated Marketfeed types.
    MsgClasses
    Identifies the specific type of a message (For example, UpdateMsg, RequestMsg etc).
    MsgKeyFlags
    Combination of bit values to indicate the presence of optional MsgKey members.
    NakCodes
    The Ack Message nakCodes, used to indicate a reason for a negative acknowledgment.
    PostMsgFlags
    The Post Message flags.
    PostUserRights
    The PostUserRights indicate whether the posting user is allowed to create or destroy items in the cache of record.
    QosRates
    Quality of service rates enumerations convey information about the data's period of change.
    QosTimeliness
    Quality Timeliness enumerations describe the age of the data.
    RealHints
    UPA Real Formatting Hint enumeration values.
    RefreshMsgFlags
    A combination of bit values that indicate special behaviors and the presence of optional RefreshMsg content.
    RequestMsgFlags
    Combination of bit values to indicate special behaviors and the presence of optional RequestMsg content.
    SeriesFlags
    A combination of bit values that indicates the presence of optional Series content.
    StateCodes
    State Codes provide additional details about the current state.
    StatusMsgFlags
    Specifies a combination of bit values indicating special behaviors and the presence of optional content.
    StreamStates
    State Stream States provide information on the health of the stream.
    UpdateMsgFlags
    A combination of bit values that indicate special behaviors and the presence of optional content.
    VectorEntryActions
    VectoryEntryAction helps to manage change processing rules and informs the consumer of how to apply the entry's data.
    VectorEntryFlags
    Combination of bit values that indicate whether optional VectorEntry content is present.
    VectorFlags
    Combination of bit values that indicate whether optional Vector content is present.

Package com.thomsonreuters.upa.codec Description

Provides classes and interfaces for encoding and decoding various messages and other data content. Besides iterators, it contains various data types that can be combined in a variety of ways to assist with modeling user's data. It also provides interfaces for messages that communicate data between system components to exchange information indicate status, permission users and access, and for a variety of other purposes. These three groups of classes and interfaces are described in the following sections:

UPA Data Types

These types manages binary representation of UPA data payload, ranging from simple primitive types through comprehensive hierarchical container types. These types are split across two categories:

  • A Primitive Type represents simple, atomically updating information. Primitive types represent values like integers, dates, and ASCII string buffers.

    A primitive type represents some type of base, system information (such as integers, dates, or array values). If contained in a set of updating information, primitive types update atomically (incoming data replaces any previously held values). Primitive types support ranges from simple primitive types (e.g., an integer) to more complex primitive types (e.g., an array). The DataTypes enumeration includes values that define the type of a primitive:

    • Values between 0 and 63 are base primitive types.Base primitive types support the full range of values allowed by the primitive type.

      Blank Data:
      When contained in a FieldEntry or ElementEntry, base primitive types can also represent a blank value. A blank value indicates that no value is currently present and any previously stored or displayed primitive value should be cleared. When decoding any base primitive value, the decode interface method returns CodecReturnCodes.BLANK_DATA. To encode blank data into a FieldEntry or ElementEntry, use encodeBlank() method.
    • Values between 64 and 127 are set-defined primitive types, which define fixed-length encodings for many of the base primitive types (e.g. INT_1 is a one byte fixed-length encoding of INT). These types can be leveraged only within a Set Definition and encoded or decoded as part of a FieldList or ElementList. Only certain set-defined primitive types can represent blank values.
  • A Container Type models more intricate data representations than UPA Primitive Types and can manage dynamic content at a more granular level. Container types represent complex types like field identifier-value, name-value, or key-value pairs. UPA offers several uniform (i.e., homogeneous) container types whose entries house the same type of data. Additionally, there are several non-uniform (i.e., heterogeneous) container types in which different entries can hold different types of data.

UPA Encode and Decode Iterators

The following sections describe high level usage of the UPA Encode and Decode Iterators. Specific iterator structure and method definitions can be found in UPA Iterator Reference Group.

  • UPA Iterator Overview When encoding or decoding RWF content with UPA, the user leverages an iterator to manage the encoding or decoding process. UPA defines a single encode iterator type (EncodeIterator) and a single decode iterator type (DecodeIterator). A single instance of this iterator can manage the full depth and breadth of the encoding or decoding process. Alternately, multiple iterator instances can be used to individually manage separate portions of the encode or decode process. See DecodeIterator for more information and code examples. The UPA encoder/decoder does not provide any inherent threading or locking capability. Separate iterator and type instances do not cause contention and do not share resources between instances. Any needed threading, locking, or thread-model implementation is at the discretion of the application. Different application threads can encode or decode different messages without requiring a lock; thus each thread must use its own iterator instance and each message should be encoded or decoded using unique and independent buffers.

    See DecodeIterator for more information and code examples for using decode iterator.
    See EncodeIterator for more information and code examples for using encode iterator.

    Note:
    Though possible, Thomson Reuters recommends that you do not encode or decode related messages (messages flowing on the same stream) on different threads as this can impact the delivery order.
  • Iterator RWF Protocol Versioning

    The UPA iterators help the user to manage version information associated with the RWF content being exchanged. When using the UPA Transport the protocol type and version information can be exchanged and negotiated on the connection (via the ConnectOptions or BindOptions). The UPA Transport will reject any connection establishment when the protocol type does not match across the connection. If the protocol type does match, an appropriate major and minor version will be determined and this should be the version of RWF encoded or decoded when using this connection. After the connection becomes active, this negotiated version information is available and can then be provided to the iterator to ensure that the proper version is encoded or decoded. If not using the UPA Transport, the user can determine the desired version of RWF to encode and specify this information on their iterator. UPA provides RWF protocol type and protocol version values in Codec for this purpose.

    Note:
    Specifying appropriate version information on DecodeIterator and EncodeIterator is important to future-proof applications and avoid incompatibility if new RWF functionality is added.

UPA Messages

The interfaces for UPA Message group manages the binary representation of UPA message headers, UPA messages and messaging constructs. There are constructs to allow for communication stream identification and to determine uniqueness of streams within a connection

See Msg for more information and code examples.
